body: I'm torn about the cost if having yet another way of rendering markdown that can introduce different behavior.

If there are any inconsistencies in behaviour, I think we can refer them to upstream - it looks like it's designed to be compatible with marked. So far the only difference I've spotted is that marked highlights GH-style code blocks if a language is specified, whereas neither mistune nor pandoc do. We can easily integrate that with pygments, which is already a requirement for nbconvert to HTML.

I've done some benchmarking with [this notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/unpingco/Python-for-Signal-Processing/blob/master/Expectation_Maximization.ipynb) from the front page of nbviewer. The fastest times I got running `time ipython nbconvert Expectation_Maximization.ipynb` repeatedly:
- node: 3.4s
- mistune: 1.2s
- pandoc: 1.8s
I don't think we should add another way to render. If we use mistune, I think it should be a replacement for something else we are doing.

I'd be inclined to do it instead of node - we don't use node anywhere else (except the proxy for the upcoming multiuser server, but many users won't need to run that), whereas we will still need the machinery to control pandoc for doing other transformations.
That's a good point. And we can make it an nbconvert dependency, so we can remove all of the check_for and fallback logic.

Yep, that would definitely simplify things.

Looking into this in a bit more detail, the code that pulls out mathematical expressions before marked gets them and puts them back afterwards is currently only implemented in JS (in `notebook/js/mathjaxutils.js`). I'm happy to port this to Python - it's a couple of hundred lines of JS, and can probably be simpler by integrating more closely with the parser.

We should probably do a run through of all of our example notebooks and a sampling of popular ones on nbviewer, so we can see any differences between them.  I would, however, consider highlighting of code blocks with a language in gfm a criterion for merge of this one.
Maybe leave the marked code there, even if it's removed from any priority list, just to make it easier to evaluate the differences between what we do in the browser and nbconvert.
I've integrated the highlighting of GFM style blocks from the example. Obviously the results are slightly different, but we already have the CSS for pygments highlighting, so it works on the page.
For the math expressions, am I right that `$foo$` is inline syntax, and `$$foo$$` is block level?
Adding mistune as an nbconvert requirement points to something else - should [notebook] imply all of the [nbconvert] dependencies? Seems like it should for simplicity, but I'm not sure.

I am +1 on using mistune instead of node and having it as the first option
that is tried.

I am less sure that [notebook] should imply all of the [nbconvert]
dependencies. But I guess it probably does make sense.

> should [notebook] imply all of the [nbconvert] dependencies? Seems like it

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

I'm not sure. On the one hand, it's perfectly possible to run the notebook server without using nbconvert, but you don't expect some of the menu options in a GUI application to require extra dependencies.

I would probably say that the [notebook] target should pull in the necessary things to render .py (/whatever language) and .html, but not e.g. latex. Though I don't think we have any extra Python deps for latex anyway.

Since we can't express the dependencies we have for pandoc, latex, etc., I think the only Python dependencies are pygments and jinja (and mistune after this PR), all of which are necessary for HTML export, so I would lean toward including them as dependencies.
After checking, I see that sphinx is listed as an nbconvert dependency in setup.py, but this isn't true, so if you touch setup.py, go ahead and remove that one.

I've integrated pass-through of maths as an extension of mistune - all fairly straightforward, though there are a few pieces that have to be subclassed together. It currently relies on mistune from Github, because I made a small change to the API (see lepture/mistune#11), so we'll need to wait for a new release before merging this. I've tested this on [a notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/unpingco/Python-for-Signal-Processing/blob/master/Expectation_Maximization.ipynb) with complex expressions, some of which I know it mangled previously; it now gets them right. Remaining differences from marked: - marked puts block-context math inside `

` tags, this currently doesn't. Easy to fix if we want to preserve that. - marked escapes `'` and `"` to `'` and `"` respectively. There isn't an obvious option to do this.
I really like this change... I think getting rid of node is a big improvement.
FYI. Mistune 0.3.0 is released now. https://github.com/lepture/mistune/tree/v0.3.0

> It describes itself as 'inspired by marked',

Actually, I introduced the renderer feature to marked.
Hi folks, please feel free to ping me on anything related to rendering mathematical equations in the notebooks.  I'm more than happy to help out.  @takluyver - is this ready for testing?

Thanks @lepture!

@ahmadia, yes, if you install the new version of mistune, this should work.

Okay, it's on my list of things to try and get done tomorrow.

Reading through the code, I don't see handling for `\begin` and `\end` blocks.  Anything between a `\begin` and `\end` statement should also be elided from MarkDown parsing.
How do I prefer it over node?  Do I have to unlink node or modify the code?
If you've got this branch, it should use mistune automatically - I took out the preference/fallback stuff, so it will only use node if you go and call `markdown2html_marked()` manually.

Okay, I tested it and it was doing the right thing when I called
_nbconvert_.

A

@ahmadia it should now work with blocks delimited by `\begin` and `\end`.
Hmn, I don't think I was testing it correctly then, because it was doing the right thing before your commit :)

That's...interesting. Did you have much math between the delimiters? The delimiters themselves get passed through to mathjax anyway, but the bits inbetween would be parsed as markdown if it wasn't handled. In the [notebook I was testing with](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/unpingco/Python-for-Signal-Processing/blob/master/Expectation_Maximization.ipynb), some underscores in expressions were getting converted to `<em>` tags before I added the maths handling.

I was trying to use `*` characters, which should have been accidentally
bolded.  I was working with the MathJaX demo notebook (but with some
intentional naughtiness).

I'm comfortable that you have implemented and tested this correctly, just
wanted to help if I could.

Thanks, testing this is definitely appreciated.

I think there are some subtleties to markdown's parsing of emphasis - e.g. `*bold*` works, but I think it ignores the asterisks both in `* foo *` and `ba*r`. I'll jump back a commit and play around with it.
